paragraphs.name: 98ed
paragraphs.text: You may have worked with managers who like to describe any sensitive decision as “Everyone is happy with”. Are they the effective and confident managers, or the opposite?

paragraphs.name: 1c38
paragraphs.text: 5. Inattention to results

paragraphs.name: d4db
paragraphs.text: This is not consensus. Consensus is horrible. Because it’s rare everyone really agrees on something naturally and quickly, consensus becomes an attempt to please everyone, which usually turns into displeasing everyone equally. Most reasonable people just need to be heard, and to know their input has been understood, considered and responded to.

paragraphs.name: 89cb
paragraphs.text: Multi-site development teams, imagine the team is spread in Japan, China, India and US. In most cases people are jockeying for positions, because of different cultural backgrounds, cost structure and other reasons, so, it is not easy to build trust!

content.subtitle: “Can everyone live with this?”, under the right context, might help driving towards “disagree and commit”.

virtuals.subtitle: “Can everyone live with this?”, under the right context, might help driving towards “disagree and commit”.

paragraphs.name: 4bb7
paragraphs.text: They seem different to me. Describing a decision as “Everyone is happy with” creates a false sense of consensus to avoid responsibility if the decision turns out to be wrong.
“Can everyone live with this?”, under the right context, might help driving towards “disagree and commit”.

That diagram is so perfect. It’s an inversion of Maslow. Instead of people achieving anything, they do the opposite under the delusions of achievment. It’s all turned into a perfect reflection of worst parts of the Christian Church: believing they’re saved without having done any work at all, except “changing their attitude” (the correlate of “giving money”).

82cf145504a7.title: I am a parliamentarian, an expert at running meetings and organizational structure.

paragraphs.name: 38d7
paragraphs.text: I am a parliamentarian, an expert at running meetings and organizational structure. One of the most frustrating and misguided ideas that I run into is that of decision making by consensus. I believe the consensus model is what led to the inability to express a clear message and the eventual implosion of the #occupy movement.

363fe39501a4.title: Yeah, the hard part is people are different.

paragraphs.text: Yeah, the hard part is people are different. We differ in culcture, geography, religion, personality, wealthy … and so on. That’s where overcoming the dysfunctions starting from vulnerability-based trust can help.
